subsection.leadIn: In this Regulation—
subsection.def: appeal (上訴) means an appeal made to the Appeal Board under section 7F of the Ordinance;
appellant (上訴人) means a person who makes an appeal;
Chairman (主席) means the Chairman of the Appeal Board appointed under section 7G(4) of the Ordinance;
notice of appeal (上訴通知) means a notice of appeal referred to in section 4(1);
Panel (備選團) means the Appeal Board Panel appointed under section 7I of the Ordinance;
party (方、一方), in relation to an appeal, means the appellant or the Director;
secretary (秘書), except in section 3, means the person who serves as secretary to the Appeal Board under section 3;
specified form (指明表格) means a form specified under section 18;
witness statement (證人陳述書) includes a statement of expert evidence (whether of fact or opinion) and an expert report.

subsection.content: All words and expressions used in this Regulation and defined in section 7A(1) of the Ordinance for the purposes of Part 7 of the Ordinance have the same meaning as in that Part.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Secretary to Appeal Board
section.content: The secretary appointed to the Panel under section 7I(8) of the Ordinance is the secretary to the Appeal Board.

subsection.content: A person aggrieved by a decision of the Director under section 7C or 7D of the Ordinance who wishes to appeal to the Appeal Board must give the secretary a notice of appeal within 30 days after the date of the notice of the decision given by the Director under that section.

subsection.leadIn: The notice of appeal must be in writing and in the specified form, and must set out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name, address and contact details of the appellant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name, address and contact details of the appellant’s authorized representative (if any);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the address at which documents relating to the appeal are to be delivered or sent to the appellant;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the particulars of the regulated product that is the subject matter of the decision under appeal; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the particulars of the decision under appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The notice of appeal must be accompanied by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the notice of the decision given by the Director under section 7C or 7D of the Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a statement setting out the grounds of appeal; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all documents on which the appellant intends to rely in support of the appeal, including witness statements.

subsection.content: The secretary must give a copy of the notice of appeal and any accompanying documents to the Director within 7 days after they are received by the secretary.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Director’s response to notice of appeal

subsection.content: The Director must, within 28 days after receipt of the copy of the notice of appeal and any accompanying documents under section 4, give a written response to the secretary.

subsection.leadIn: The Director’s response—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must state whether or not the Director intends to oppose the appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Director intends to oppose the appeal, must set out the grounds of opposition; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by all documents on which the Director intends to rely in opposing the appeal, including witness statements.

subsection.content: The Director must, within the period mentioned in subsection (1), give a copy of the Director’s response and any accompanying documents to the appellant.

The Appeal Board may at any time give directions that it considers necessary or desirable for clarifying the issues arising on the appeal and generally as it considers necessary or desirable for the just disposal of the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the Appeal Board may give directions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: requiring a party to provide to the Appeal Board any particulars or supplementary statements (including witness statements), or any documents or other material in the party’s custody or control, as it may reasonably require for the determination of the appeal, and to give a copy to the other party;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specifying the time within which and manner in which any particulars, statements, documents or material or copies are to be provided or given as the Appeal Board may consider reasonable;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: requiring any person to attend as a witness at a hearing of the appeal and to answer any questions, or produce any documents or other material in the person’s custody or control, which relate to any matter in question in the appeal; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: prohibiting or restricting the publication, disclosure or use of any particulars, statements, documents or material or copies provided or given in response to the Appeal Board’s directions or any answers, documents or other material given or produced at a hearing.

subsection.leadIn: In exercising its powers under subsection (2)(d), the Appeal Board must take into account the need to protect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: intimate personal and financial information;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: commercially sensitive information; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: information communicated or obtained in confidence.

subsection.content: Despite subsections (1) and (2), no person may be compelled to give any evidence or provide or produce any document or other material that the person could not be compelled to give, provide or produce at a trial of an action in a court of law.
If the appellant does not comply with any directions given to the appellant under section 6, the Appeal Board may, at any stage of the proceedings, dismiss the whole or any part of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: If the Director does not comply with any directions given to the Director under section 6, the Appeal Board may, at any stage of the proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: strike out the whole or any part of the Director’s response; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where appropriate, remit the decision under appeal to the Director for reconsideration.

subsection.content: The Appeal Board may exercise its powers under subsection (1) or (2) against a party to the appeal only if the Appeal Board has given that party notice of its intention to exercise those powers and has given that party not less than 21 days to make representations to the Appeal Board as to why it should not exercise those powers.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Date, time and place of hearing

subsection.leadIn: Unless an appeal is wholly disposed of under section 7 or 9, the secretary must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appoint a date, time and place for the hearing of the appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least 21 days before the date appointed, give to each party to the appeal a notice in writing of the date, time and place.

subsection.content: At least 7 days before the date appointed for the hearing of the appeal, each party must inform the Appeal Board and the other party in writing whether the party wishes to attend the hearing, either in person or by an authorized representative.

subsection.leadIn: A party who wishes to attend the hearing of the appeal must, at least 7 days before the date appointed for the hearing, provide the Appeal Board and the other party with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: particulars of the evidence the party intends to adduce at the hearing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: particulars of the documents the party intends to produce at the hearing; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the names of the persons the party intends to call as witnesses.

subsection.content: A party who does not wish to attend the hearing of the appeal may, at least 7 days before the date appointed for the hearing, give to the Appeal Board additional written representations (including witness statements).

A party who gives additional written representations to the Appeal Board under subsection (4) must, at least 7 days before the date appointed for the hearing of the appeal, give a copy of those representations to the other party.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director’s response is not received by the Appeal Board within the period mentioned in section 5(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the Director informs the Appeal Board in writing that the Director—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: does not oppose the appeal; or

subsection.continued: the Appeal Board must determine the appeal by remitting the decision under appeal to the Director for reconsideration.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may dismiss an appeal without an oral hearing if, after having given the appellant an opportunity to make representations, the Appeal Board is of the opinion that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the issues raised on the appeal have been determined on a previous appeal brought by the appellant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the previous appeal was brought on the basis of facts which do not materially differ from those to which the appeal in question relates.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may determine an appeal without an oral hearing if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: both parties to the appeal agree in writing that the appeal is to be determined without an oral hearing; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: both parties inform the Appeal Board in writing that they do not wish to attend the hearing.

subsection.leadIn: Before the Appeal Board meets to determine an appeal without an oral hearing under subsection (3), the secretary must inform the parties in writing of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Appeal Board’s intention to meet to determine the appeal without an oral hearing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date, time and place at which the Appeal Board is to meet to determine the appeal.

subsection.content: In determining an appeal without an oral hearing under subsection (3), the Appeal Board must consider the parties’ written submissions.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (5)—

def.name: WrittenSubmissions
def.leadIn: written submissions (書面陳述), in relation to a party to an appeal, includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of the appellant, the notice of appeal and any accompanying documents mentioned in section 4(3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of the Director, the Director’s response and any accompanying documents mentioned in section 5(2)(c);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any particulars, statements, documents or material provided by that party in response to the Appeal Board’s directions under section 6; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any additional written representations given by that party under section 8(4).

subsection.content: This section applies whether or not a notice of hearing has been given under section 8.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Hearings to be in public except in special circumstances

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2), (3) and (4), a hearing before the Appeal Board must be held in public.

subsection.leadIn: If the Appeal Board is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so, it may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct that a hearing or part of a hearing is to take place in private and give directions as to the persons who may be present at the hearing; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the publication or disclosure to either or both of the parties to the appeal, or to some or all of the persons who may be present at the hearing, of any evidence given before the Appeal Board or of any matter contained in any document given to the Appeal Board or received in evidence by it; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the publication, disclosure or use by either or both of the parties, or by some or all of the persons who may be present at the hearing, of any evidence, matter or document referred to in subparagraph (i).

subsection.content: The Appeal Board may exercise its powers under subsection (2)(b) in relation to any evidence, matter or document, whether or not it has given directions under section 6(2)(d) in respect of that evidence, matter or document.

subsection.leadIn: In exercising its powers under subsection (2), the Appeal Board must take into account the need to protect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: intimate personal and financial information;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: commercially sensitive information; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: information communicated or obtained in confidence.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Failure of party to attend hearing

subsection.leadIn: If a party to an appeal, having been given a notice of hearing under section 8, fails to attend the hearing, either in person or by an authorized representative, the Appeal Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proceed to hear and determine the appeal in the party’s absence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the appellant fails to attend the hearing, dismiss the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board must not exercise its powers under subsection (1) against a party if, before the time appointed for the hearing, that party—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: informs the Appeal Board in writing that the party will not be able to attend the hearing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: satisfies the Appeal Board that the party has sufficient reason for not doing so.

subsection.content: The Appeal Board may conduct the hearing in any manner it considers most suitable for the just disposal of the proceedings.
Either party to the appeal may attend the hearing, either in person or by an authorized representative (including a legal representative).
The parties are entitled to give evidence, to call witnesses, to question any witnesses and to address the Appeal Board both on the evidence and generally on the subject matter of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receive and consider any material that the Appeal Board considers relevant, whether by way of oral evidence, witness statements, documents or otherwise, and whether or not the material would be admissible in proceedings before a court of law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by notice in writing signed by the Chairman, require any person to attend before it at any hearing and to give evidence and produce documents or other material;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: require any witness to give evidence on oath or affirmation;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: examine on oath, affirmation or otherwise any person attending before it and require the person to answer all questions put by or with the consent of the Appeal Board; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: determine the manner in which the material referred to in paragraph (a) is to be received.

subsection.content: Any member of the Appeal Board may administer oaths or affirmations for the purposes of this section.

Despite subsection (4), no person may be compelled to give any evidence or produce any document or other material that the person could not be compelled to give or produce at a trial of an action in a court of law.
The Chairman may at any stage of the proceedings adjourn a hearing to a later time or date.
An appellant may, at any time, abandon the appeal or any part of the appeal by notice in writing given to the secretary.
An appellant who gives a notice under subsection (1) must give a copy of the notice to the Director.

The Chairman may, on an application made in writing by a party to an appeal, extend any period of time prescribed by this Regulation or specified by the Appeal Board for doing any act and may impose conditions with respect to the extension.

If the Chairman grants an extension of time, the Chairman may, if the Chairman thinks fit, without hearing the party in whose favour the extension is granted, grant a reasonable extension of the period of time in which the other party is required to take any subsequent step.
A period of time may be extended either before or after the period in question has expired.

If any period of time prescribed by this Regulation, or specified by the Appeal Board, for doing any act is extended in relation to an appeal, this Regulation has effect in relation to the appeal as if references in this Regulation to that period were references to that period as extended.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Appeal Board to regulate own procedure
section.content: Subject to this Regulation, the Appeal Board may regulate its own procedure.

subsection.leadIn: The secretary must make or cause to be made in writing a summary of the following matters in respect of every appeal determined by the Appeal Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name of the appellant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name of any person who gives evidence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the grounds of the appeal;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the major findings of facts;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the decision of the Appeal Board and the reasons for the decision;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any other matters directed by the Appeal Board to be recorded in the summary.

subsection.content: The summary taken under subsection (1) must be signed by the Chairman.
A decision by the Appeal Board, if not unanimous, is to be that of the majority of the members of the Appeal Board.

As soon as practicable after the Appeal Board has determined an appeal, the secretary must send to each party to the appeal a notice in writing of the Appeal Board’s decision and a statement of the reasons for the decision.
The Secretary for Health (referred to in this section as the Secretary) may specify the forms to be used for the purposes of this Regulation. (L.N. 144 of 2022)
The Secretary is to make available, on request, copies of the specified forms during office hours at the office of the Secretary.
The Secretary is to make available copies of the specified forms through any other means that the Secretary considers appropriate.

Any document (however described) that is required or authorized by this Regulation to be given, provided or sent to the Appeal Board, the Chairman, an appellant, the Director or any other person must be delivered in person or sent by post.
Any document (however described) delivered in person or sent by post to the Appeal Board or the Chairman under this Regulation must be addressed to the secretary.
Any application made to the Appeal Board or the Chairman under this Regulation must be addressed to the secretary.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Witness statements to be made on oath or affirmation

subsection.content: A witness statement must be made on oath or affirmation.
The Appeal Board may waive the requirement in subsection (1) in respect of certain witness statements or classes of witness statements, whether before or after the witness statements are made.

The Appeal Board may refuse to consider, for the purposes of determining an appeal, any witness statement if the requirement in subsection (1) is not complied with in respect of the witness statement and is not waived in respect of it.
This section does not affect the Appeal Board’s power to receive and consider any material under section 12(4).

section.name: s21
section.heading: Offence for false or misleading information

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes any statement or representation or furnishes any information, to the Appeal Board or the Chairman for the purposes of an appeal, that the person knows to be false or misleading in a material respect; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recklessly makes any statement or representation or furnishes any information, to the Appeal Board or the Chairman for the purposes of an appeal, that is false or misleading in a material respect.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 3 of 2022)
